results.headline: Making Music With Comedy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Punching the Clown

results.summary_short: What holds “Punching the Clown” together is the quiet charm of its star, Henry Phillips.

results.headline: On the Streets of Lisbon, Love, Romance and Desire

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Portuguese Nun

results.summary_short: Eugène Green’s film “The Portuguese Nun” is infused with a melancholy intensity that is both seductive and strange.

results.headline: He’s a Big Man on a Mission

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Knucklehead

results.summary_short: The professional wrestler Paul Wight — who goes by the name the Big Show — stars in a family comedy with a dose of crassness and violence.

results.headline: A Life-Saving Journey to the Dark Side

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Inhale

results.summary_short: A man trying to save his ailing daughter gets an unflattering look at Juárez in Baltasar Kormakur’s latest film, “Inhale.”

results.headline: A Hairy Love Situation

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of BearCity

results.summary_short: “BearCity” covers a fair bit of emotional territory, although without amounting to much especially profound.

results.headline: The Dead Have Messages for the Land of the Living

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hereafter

results.summary_short: A new film from Clint Eastwood contemplates whether the end of life is really the end.

results.headline: The Days, Nights and Years of the Jackal: The Tale of a Terrorist

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Carlos

results.summary_short: The French director Olivier Assayas dramatizes the life and murderous times of the terrorist Carlos the Jackal.

results.headline: Seeking Vengeance in High Heels

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ticked-Off Trannies With Knives

results.summary_short: “Ticked-Off Trannies With Knives” calls itself an exploitation thriller and seeks to parody bad horror films.

results.headline: Wordless and Lost, a Young Couple Flee

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Samson & Delilah

results.summary_short: In “Samson & Delilah,” two Aboriginal teenagers become outcasts in their scraggly Australian village and flee to an even harsher urban life.

results.headline: Who Ya Callin’ Gramps, Junior?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Red

results.summary_short: “RED” features Bruce Willis and a squad of geezers who still know how to fire automatic weapons.

results.headline: After a Death, Friendships and Secrets

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nora's Will

results.summary_short: “Nora’s Will” is about secrets and lies and a narrative imperative that every unhappy life must end not only with death but with closure too.

results.headline: Maximum Gross Outs in Sleazy, Queasy Stunts

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jackass 3D

results.summary_short: The painful pranks of “Jackass 3D” still elicit some of the inexplicable and queasy pleasure of the previous movies, but the franchise might have jumped the shark.

results.headline: The Dark Art of Drawing Political Lines

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gerrymandering

results.summary_short: Jeff Reichert’s documentary looks at the long history of shaping electoral districts for political ends.

results.headline: Trying to Sniff Out a Rat Hiding in a Toxic World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Down Terrace

results.summary_short: Ben Wheatley’s deadpan crime comedy, “Down Terrace,” features a real father-and-son team.

results.headline: Her Brother’s Keeper, No Matter the Cost

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Conviction

results.summary_short: Hilary Swank plays Betty Anne Waters in “Conviction,” about a sister’s dogged effort to free a brother sentenced to life for murder.

results.headline: Romance in Brazil’s Wild West

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Carmo, Hit the Road

results.summary_short: “Carmo, Hit the Road” ambles through some beautiful jungle-and-river landscapes without really going anywhere.

results.headline: Hungry for Revenge

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bitter Feast

results.summary_short: “Bitter Feast” is a low-budget abduction thriller about a maliciously snarky restaurant critic, a sociopathic celebrity chef and an isolated estate deep in the woods.

results.headline: A Multitasking Nun in Medieval Germany

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vision

results.summary_short: A period drama by Margarethe von Trotta shows the life of the medieval nun and scholar Hildegard of Bingen.

results.headline: How to Make the Grim Appear Artfully Beautiful

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Darkness of Day

results.summary_short: Jay Rosenblatt’s “Darkness of Day”considers a friend’s suicide in a skillful and stately way.

results.headline: Death Reclaims His Fractured Psyche

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Soul to Take

results.summary_short: “My Soul to Take” has the comic pop-culture references and dreamy shocks of a Wes Craven film, but the director’s heart does not seem to be into it.
